Identification of surface species and methanation reactions on palladium/zirconia catalysts C. Schild, A. Wokaun* Physical Chemistry II, University of Bayreuth, P.O. Box 101251, D-8580 Bayreuth (F.R.G.) and A. Baiker Department of Industrial and Engineering Chemistry, Swiss Federal Institute of Technology, ETH Zentrum, CH-8092 Zurich (Switzerland) (Received April 10, 1990; revised June 11, 1990) Abstract Hydrogenation reactions over zirconia-supported palladium catalysts have been investigated by diffuse reflectance FTIR spectroscopy. Catalysts obtained by activation of an amorphous Pdz5Zr75 precursor, as well as catalysts prepared by wet impregnation of zirconia, were characterized in flowing CO/Hg or COz/Hg reactant gases, respectively, in the temperature range 298 473 K. In addition, species present on the catalyst surface under equilibrated conditions were studied in the static system, after the gas flow was terminated. Sup- plementary information was obtained by studying the surface reactions occurring when the catalyst was first exposed to reaction conditions, and subsequently to a stream of pure hydrogen. Surface species were identified by comparison with adsorption studies in which the catalysts were loaded with reference compounds (C02, formaldehyde, methanol and methanol^), and the surface spectrum recorded as a function of temperature. Upon exposure to COa/Hg, rapid formation of surface formate was observed. Similarly, CO was rapidly transformed to formate upon initial adsorption onto the surface of the activated catalysts. The disappearance of formate, as observed in the FTIR spectrum, could be correlated with the appearance of gas phase methane. A second major route of surface reactions, which proceeds from CO/Ha mixtures, involves adsorbed CO, TT- bonded formaldehyde, surface-bound methylate, and gas phase methanol as the product. Interestingly, there was no observable correlation between adsorbed formaldehyde or methylate on the one hand, and gas phase methane on the other hand. The steps involved in the surface reactions on zirconia and palladium/zirconia are discussed in detail, by comparison with the reactions observed when the catalysts were exposed to reference compounds relevant to the reaction mechanism. Introduction During the last two decades, extensive work has been carried out in examining the mechanism of catalytic hydrogenation reactions of CO and COg which produce methanol and methane. Many investigations were devoted Author to whom correspondence should be addressed. 0304-5102/90/$3.50 Elsevier Sequoia/Printed in The Netherlands 224 to the question which of the two reactants, carbon monoxide or carbon dioxide, is the most effective starting material for the production of methanol. Another issue that has been intensively discussed is whether the reactions proceed via surface formate or via other intermediates [1, 2]. In Klier's review [ 1 ] three basic mechanisms of adsorbed CO hydrogenation are discussed: carbon-down, oxygen-down and side-on hydrogenation. The latter pathway to methanol is not impeded by large thermodynamic barriers and therefore feasible, but adsorbed formaldehyde as an intermediate in that path has never been observed. However, it was shown that for at least one catalyst, Rh/TiOg, a second C 0 bond was not formed during CO hydro- genation, which indicates that methanol synthesis does not require formate as an intermediate [3]. Klier [1] concludes that palladium, platinum, iridium and copper will behave similarly to the Rh/TiOg catalyst, and will not favour the formate route to methanol. The alternative oxygen-down hydrogenation involves formate as a precursor of methoxide and methanol, and has been discussed for ZnO catalysts [2]. Klier's conclusion is confirmed by Hicks and Bell [5], who find that the presence of formates on supported palladium catalysts is not correlated with the kinetics of methanol synthesis. The reaction to methanol is therefore suggested to proceed via a hydroxymethylene [Me CH(OH) Me] rather than a formate intermediate. In contrast, Kikuzono et al. [4] propose a mechanism in which formate is hydrogenated to methanol on Pd/SiOg catalysts. In Part I of their methanol synthesis review, Chinchen et al. [6] point out that carbon dioxide may also be hydrogenated to methanol on supported palladium, with the formation of surface formate as the first step. From the fact that formates have been observed on palladium-based methanol synthesis catalysts, Chinchen et al. [6] conclude, in direct contradiction to Klier [I], that formate may also be a common intermediate in the rhodium-based methanation and methanol synthesis catalysts. In an investigation of COg hydrogenation, Ramaroson et al. [7] de- monstrate a support dependence of the selectivity to either methanol (Pd/ Laa03) or methane (Pd/SiOg). Investigations by Erdohelyi et al. [8] with palladium on various supports suggest that formate, as an intermediate in COg hydrogenation, can be hydrogenated to methane to a great extent, but not to methanol. Diagne et al. [9] have studied CO hydrogenation over Pd/ CeOg and CeOa catalysts. They conclude that fonnyl species are involved in methanol synthesis on Pd/CeOa surfaces, whereas on CeOg formate species were detected as intermediates [9]. In this study we shall address the following questions: (a) Which intermediates can be observed on the surface of our zirconia- supported metal catalysts during the hydrogenation of COa and CO? (b) Is it possible to correlate the occurrence of certain intermediates with the predominance of either hydrogenation product, methanol or methane? (c) Can it be distinguished whether methanol formation proceeds from COg or CO as the immediate precursor? Under the reaction conditions used, C02 and CO can potentially be interconverted by the water-gas shift reaction. 225 (d) Are there indications of the origin of the different product selectivity patterns that have been observed for the various catalysts? During hydro- genation of COg over copper/zirconia catalysts, methanol is produced as the main product, with selectivities depending on reaction conditions [10]. Palladium/zirconia catalysts prepared by wet impregnation predominantly produce methane under the same conditions [11]. Only recently it has been observed that for palladium/ZrCXr catalysts prepared by activation of amorphous PdiZrg alloys, methanol is obtained with selectivities up to "45% [11]. The first three questions will be addressed in Part I, in which results for palladium/zirconia catalyst systems are presented. The factors that de- termine the selectivity to methanol (question d)) will be discussed in Part II, by comparing the spectroscopic evidence obtained on Cu/ZrOg and Pd/ ZrOg catalysts. Experimental Spectra were recorded on an FTIR spectrometer (Perkin-Elmer, model 1710) using a diffuse reflectance unit equipped with a controlled environmental chamber (Spectra Tech). The temperature in the chamber could be controlled within 2 K. The spectrometer and temperature controller were connected to a personal computer (Nixdorf, AT 386) for data handling and processing. The gas dosing system was designed to introduce up to three gases independently into the reaction chamber. The gas flows were adjusted to the desired values using volume flow controllers (Rota). Liquid reagents were introduced by bubbling nitrogen through a sealed flask containing the liquid. Nitrogen (Linde, 99.999%) as the carrier gas, as well as carbon dioxide (Linde, 99.9993%), carbon monoxide (Linde, 99.997%) and hydrogen (Linde, 99.999%) as reactants were used without further purification. High purity methanol and methanol-d4 served as reference compounds in the adsorption experiments. Formaldehyde was adsorbed from a 37% aqueous solution containing 10% methanol for stabilization. The catalyst samples under in- vestigation were prepared from an amorphous precursor (Pda5Zr75), and by wet impregnation of a precipitated zirconia support (Pd/ZrOg, 5 wt.% pal- ladium), according to the procedure reported in an earlier investigation [11]. Before the FTIR measurements, the catalysts are reactivated in hydrogen flow at elevated temperatures (450 500 K) for several hours. During this procedure care must be taken to choose a low heating rate (<5 K min~1): the samples derived from the amorphous precursor, in particular, have a surface structure which is sensitive and unstable with respect to rapid heating. After reactivation, the background spectrum is collected at the temperature to be maintained during the following catalytic reaction (453 473 K). A defined flow of the gaseous reactants, with the desired pre-adjusted compo- sition, is passed over the sample at a total pressure of about 3X105 Pa. Subsequently the surface reaction is studied by recording time-resolved FTIR 226 spectra at a resolution of 4 or 8 cm"1, respectively. From 20 to 500 scans were accumulated, depending upon the system and the time scale on which time-dependent changes had to be resolved. Gaseous reaction products are easily detected by closing the in- and outlet valves of the reaction chamber; this situation will be referred to as a 'static system'. In the 'dynamic' experiments a continuous flow of reactants is passed through the chamber, gaseous products being purged. By the latter technique, the observation of adsorbate vibrations is not impeded by strong overlapping signals of gaseous products. Results In the following sections, diffuse reflectance FTIR spectra will be presented that were recorded on palladium/zirconia catalysts under a set of defined reaction conditions. Four major types of surface species have been observed, which were identified as surface carbonates, surface formate, adsorbed formaldehyde and methanol or surface-bound methylate, respectively. These intermediates have been identified by comparison with reference spectra in the literature, and by adsorption experiments in which the substrate under study was covered with the compound that was postulated to represent the surface intermediate. To facilitate interpretation of spectra recorded during the catalytic runs, the results from the adsorption of reference compounds will be reported first. Representative spectra of surface carbonates, formate, adsorbed for- maldehyde and methylates are presented below. Adsorption experiments of CO and COg on the zirconia support as well as on Pd (5 wt.%)/Zr02 are described in the subsequent section; the hydrogenation of carbon monoxide and carbon dioxide over palladium/zirconia is investigated thereafter. Copper/ zirconia catalysts prepared both from amorphous precursors and by preci- pitation will be discussed in Part II of this study. Vibrational spectra of adsorbed reference compounds Surface carbonates and surface formate Spectra of carbonates and formates bound to the surface of oxide supports have been reported in the literature [12]. In the form which is thermally stable up to higher temperatures, COg2" is bound to the surface through a single oxygen ion, as a monodentate ligand. The second negative charge of COg2" is delocalized over two partial double bonds, giving rise to two vibrations of comparatively low frequency. Ranges of 1420 1540 cm"1 and 1330 1390 cm~1 are indicated in the literature [12]. In the bidentate form, which is generally less stable, carbonate is bound to the surface via two oxygen ion bridges. This geometry, with one double bond directed away from the surface, is characterized by a band in the 1600-1670 cm'' range, with the C 0 (single bond) stretching vibration between 1280 and 1310 cm"1. On zirconia supports, surface-bound formate is characterized by a C H stretching vibration at 2875 cm~1, the asymmetric stretch of the carboxylate group at 1580 cm ', and the symmetric stretching vibration at 1370 cm"1 [13]. Formaldehyde adsorption The C=0 stretching vibration of gaseous formaldehyde appears at a frequency of 1744 cm"1; absorptions at 2874 and 2780 cm~1 are assigned to C-H stretching, and bands at 1503, 1280 and 1167 cm"1 correspond to C H deformational vibrations [14]. Upon adsorption of formaldehyde on Pd/ZrOg from a 37% aqueous solution, which also contains some methanol as a stabilizer, one observes several absorptions in the room temperature spectrum (Fig. I): Bands centered at 2850, 1580 and 1370 cm~1 are due to surface formate; a weak band around 1050 cm"' is assigned to the C 0 stretching vibration of methanol; and a band at 1620 cm"1, which appears as a shoulder on the 1580 cm~1 band, originates from surface-bound water. Further signals are observed around 1850 and 1150 cm~1, the latter band of which is due to a surface-bound species arising from formaldehyde as the immediate precursor. No formaldehyde, methylate or methanol absorptions are observed under C02 hydrogenation conditions. Species that are unique to the CO/Hg system include surface methylate, methanol and surface formaldehyde. For impregnated palladium/zirconia catalysts, for- maldehyde and methylate are only observed when starting from CO/Hg mixtures. The observed correlations of surface and gas phase species are summarized in the reaction scheme of Fig. 14. Adsorbates are grouped around the reactants CO and COg which, in the presence of hydrogen, are interconverted on the catalyst surface by the water-gas shift reaction. 241 The left side of the diagram represents the observed reactions that produce methane via surface formate. We have so far not been able to establish unambiguously whether the latter intermediate is formed from surface carbonate, or from COg and Hg by some other mechanism (dashed arrows). In an experiment designed to elucidate this question, the catalyst surface was first loaded with carbonates by exposure to pure COg. Subsequently the gas phase was purged with nitrogen, and then hydrogen was admitted. In this experiment the formation of surface formate proceeds considerably more slowly, as compared to the situation where both COg and hydrogen are present in the gas phase. It thus appears that surface carbonate does not necessarily act as an intermediate in the formation of surface formate; rather, a direct pathway from COg and Hg appears to dominate. The right hand side of the diagram represents the suggested sequence of hydrogenation steps leading from adsorbed CO, via ir-bonded formaldehyde and methylate as the intermediates, to the gaseous methanol product. The importance of the two sides of the reaction scheme (methane and methanol paths) appears to depend largely on the structural properties of the zirconia-supported palladium catalyst. Although the present IR investi- gations reflect the earlier observed differences in selectivity behavior [11] of the differently prepared palladium/zirconia catalysts, they do not allow clarification of this point completely. In this context, attention is drawn to the interesting observation that CO is adsorbed more strongly on the palladium particles of the impregnated catalyst than on the palladium of the catalyst derived from amorphous Pd^r^. This behavior is attributed to the different structural and morphological properties of the impregnated catalyst, and the catalyst derived from amorphous Pd Zr. These differences concern both the structure of the zirconia and the palladium-zirconia interface [18]. In the catalyst prepared by wet impregnation, the crystalline palladium particles are in relatively loose contact with the support Qarge contact angle, poor wetting), and consequently form a comparatively small interfacial area with the crystalline and stoichiometric zirconia. In contrast, in the palladium/ zirconia catalysts derived from amorphous Pd Zr alloys, the small palladium particles are intermeshed in the surrounding amorphous zirconia phase, forming an extremely large interfacial area. Regarding the metal particle size, the results of Fajula et al. [19] should be mentioned. These authors have suggested that on small palladium particles CO is weakly adsorbed, which leads mainly to methanol formation, while on larger palladium particles, CO is adsorbed more strongly and preferentially forms methane under CO hydrogenation conditions. Whereas this influence of the palladium particle size may be one important factor in the explanation of the different selectivities, the situation is even more complex for the two catalysts investigated in this study, as the structural and chemical properties of the interface and of the zirconia also largely differ between the two systems. In the catalyst derived from Pd Zr, part of the zirconia exists as oxygen-deficient ZrOg-a; [20]. For a final answer concerning the origin of the different selectivities observed, the role of these oxygen vacancies for 242 the two reaction paths (methane, methanol) needs to be clarified. Baiker Department of Industrial and Engineering Chemistry, Swiss Federal Institute of Technology, ETH Zentrum, CH-8092 ZurichSwitzerland Hydrogenation reactions over zirconia-supported palladium catalysts have been investigated by diffuse reflectance FTIR spectroscopy. Catalysts obtained by activation of an amorphous Pd25Zr75 precursor, as well as catalysts prepared by wet impregnation of zirconia, were characterized in flowing CO/H2 or CO2/H2 reactant gases, respectively, in the temperature range 298–473 K. In addition, species present on the catalyst surface under equilibrated conditions were studied in the static system, after the gas flow was terminated. Supplementary information was obtained by studying the surface reactions occurring when the catalyst was first exposed to reaction conditions, and subsequently to a stream of pure hydrogen. Surface species were identified by comparison with adsorption studies in which the catalysts were loaded with reference compounds (CO2, formaldehyde, methanol and methanol-d4), and the surface spectrum recorded as a function of temperature. Upon exposure to CO2/H2, rapid formation of surface formate was observed. Similarly, CO was rapidly transformed to formate upon initial adsorption onto the surface of the activated catalysts. The disappearance of formate, as observed in the FTIR spectrum, could be correlated with the appearance of gas phase methane. A second major route of surface reactions, which proceeds from CO/H2 mixtures, involves adsorbed CO, π-bonded formaldehyde, surface-bound methylate, and gas phase methanol as the product. Interestingly, there was no observable correlation between adsorbed formaldehyde or methylate on the one hand, and gas phase methane on the other hand. The steps involved in the surface reactions on zirconia and palladium/zirconia are discussed in detail, by comparison with the reactions observed when the catalysts were exposed to reference compounds relevant to the reaction mechanism.
